description: A vibrant community of learning that endeavors to fulfill its informal motto, ''in the nation's service and the service of humanity.'' (Alumni note: The "Notable Alumni" section is generated by LinkedIn.)
name: Princeton University
tagline: Princeton in the nation’s service and the service of humanity.

updates.text:
At the end of World War II, the United States was left with a set of advanced research facilities, originally set up in the race to produce nuclear weapons. Rather than stopping the science, the Department of Energy gave these facilities permanent peacetime missions by transforming them into a system of national labs. Can you find our very own Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory (PPPL)? 🔎 

Take the tour to learn more: https://bit.ly/4fdNDu7

2021 Nobel laureate in literature Abdulrazak Gurnah shared reflections on literature, compassion and the “oceanic cosmopolitanism” that connects artists and thinkers across continents during a visit to Princeton: https://bit.ly/3AKoGIo

Gurnah’s visit was hosted by the University’s Africa World Initiative, a multifaceted program to cultivate partnerships with wide-ranging impact in and beyond Africa.

#TellUsTigers: "As president of the Princeton Triangle Club, I’m incredibly excited about the world premiere this weekend of the 134th Triangle Show, ‘Pageant Pending’ — where an aspiring reporter is unexpectedly swept into the pageant world! I joined Triangle as the stage manager in my first-year spring and was quickly introduced to the Triangle tradition. Triangle has been creating original musical comedy — written and performed by students, directed and choreographed by professionals — on the McCarter Theatre Center stage since 1891. I can say that leading the club and producing the show have been truly rewarding opportunities. My heart bursts with love, pride and gratitude for all the people of Triangle who have supported me along the way and become some of my closest friends. They motivate me to be a better leader and make all the late nights at the theater worthwhile. I often get puzzled looks when I tell people I’m in Triangle and I’m an architecture major — as both require extensive periods of time in a dedicated space: the theater and the studio. Yet, these two important aspects of my Princeton experience overlap greatly. Mounting a new musical and creating an architecture model both start with a blank page, prompting a creative process that can take months, sometimes years, to culminate in a single moment: a live performance or studio review. For me, the thrill of seeing a collaborative project come to life in front of an audience is unparalleled."— Vera Fei '26; photo by Noel Valero '82 *86 More info about "Pageant Pending": https://bit.ly/3AD3hAP
From Paris To Princeton! 👏 9 of our 26 summer Olympians recently returned to campus to be recognized by the home crowd at Princeton Stadium. 🧡🖤 #OlympiansMadeHere

Juliette C. '24 and Collin Riggins '24 are the latest recipients of the Dale Fellowship, which funds yearlong independent projects for members of each senior class in the year following their graduation.

For her Dale project, Carbonnier is writing a one-woman play with music inspired by the legacy of her ancestors, some of whom were progressive Yiddish performers, comedians and composers, while others were Holocaust survivors.

For his Dale project, “Cotton Stains,” Riggins is producing a collection of black-and-white analog photographs of Black cotton farmers. He is also working to develop a public art studio in Garysburg, North Carolina, to support creatives in the area.

Learn more about this year's fellows: https://bit.ly/3UNAksM

The annual Veterans Day service, held jointly between #PrincetonU and the Spirit of Princeton, honored those veterans in our community, including the 1,286 current employees and retirees who have served, as well as the 13 veteran employees and retirees and 216 veteran alumni who have passed over the past year.

At the ceremony, US Navy Captain Kelley T. Jones provided remarks, Matthew Cline '27 performed Taps, and #PrincetonU Electric Shop supervisor Kenneth Grayson sang America the Beautiful.

Coinciding with the 125th anniversary of the Princeton University Graduate School, all alumni are invited back to campus for the “Many Minds, Many Stripes” conference on Oct. 9-11, 2025: https://bit.ly/4fD0WEN

How do you move a mounted dinosaur? With a skeleton crew. 

After more than 60 years of being on display in Guyot Hall, “Al” the Allosaurus is wintering in Canada before being re-installed across in the new Environmental Sciences building, the future home of Geosciences Princeton University, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology and the High Meadows Environmental Institute. 

More on what's next for Al: https://bit.ly/4ekJaFd

Today is National First-Generation College Celebration Day, a time to celebrate the achievements of students, faculty, staff and alumni who are among the first in their families to attend college and highlight the important contributions that first-gen students make within their communities. 

Established in 2021, through a gift from Bloomberg Philanthropies, the Emma Bloomberg Center for Access & Opportunity supports and empowers students –especially those from first-generation an lower-income backgrounds– to, through and beyond college: https://bit.ly/3CiYkh7

Professor emeritus William Chester Jordan *73 has been awarded the 2024 Barry Prize for Distinguished Intellectual Achievement for his work "bridging the social, economic, religious, and political dimensions of life ... unlock[ing] the mysteries of medieval Europe for contemporary readers": https://bit.ly/3UHCjPn
